snippet: The killing of John Valluzzo at his sprawling Connecticut home last week did not follow the more familiar story line that evokes Amadou Diallo or other police killings.
abstract: Shooting by police of John Valluzzo at his Ridgefield, Conn, home, does not follow more familiar story line that evokes Amadou Diallo or other police killings; details of the shooting remain uncertain, but the impact is devastating, especially for friends and relatives of Valluzzo, who was successful 75-year-old businessman and philanthropist; Jorge Romero, policeman who shot him, is well-liked veteran who was a rare minority officer in a virtually all-white department.

byline.original: By PETER APPLEBOME and ELIZABETH MAKER
byline.contributor: Kristin Hussey contributed reporting from Stamford, Conn., Lisa Schwartz from New York City, and Eric Silverstadt from Ridgefield.

lead_paragraph: The killing of John Valluzzo at his sprawling Connecticut home last week did not follow the more familiar story line that evokes Amadou Diallo or other police killings.

headline.seo: In Connecticut, a Police Killing That Seemed to Go Against Type
headline.main: A Police Killing That Seemed to Go Against Type
headline.print_headline: Police Killing In Connecticut Reverses Norm
